entry.et: Middle English dul; akin to Old English dol foolish, Old Irish dall blind

def.dt: :slow in perception or sensibility :insensible somewhat dull of hearing
:lacking zest or vivacity :listless a dull performance
:lacking in force, intensity, or sharpness a dull ache
:not resonant or ringing a dull booming sound
:lacking sharpness of edge or point a dull knife
:lacking brilliance or luster a dull finish
:low in saturation and low in lightness

entry.pt: dull blunt obtuse mean not sharp, keen, or acute. dull suggests a lack or loss of keenness, zest, or pungency a dull pain a dull mind. blunt suggests an inherent lack of sharpness or quickness of feeling or perception a person of blunt sensibility. obtuse implies such bluntness as makes one insensitive in perception or imagination too obtuse to take the hint.

def.dt: :to make dull dull a knife's edge
